greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Continued fraction expansion for exp( Sum_{n>=1} 1/(n*A014448(n)) ), where A014448(n) = (2+sqrt(5))^n + (2-sqrt(5))^n.
link: Index entries for linear recurrences with constant coefficients, signature (0,0,19,0,0,-19,0,0,1).
P. Bala, Some simple continued fraction expansions for an infinite product, Part 1
P. Bala, Some simple continued fraction expansions for an infinite product, Part 2
formula: The above conjectures are correct. The real number exp( Sum {n>=1} 1/(n*A014448(n)) ) is equal to the infinite product F(x) := product {n >= 0} (1 + x^(4*n+3))/(1 - x^(4*n+1)) evaluated at x = sqrt(5) - 2. Ramanujan has given a continued fraction expansion for the product F(x). Using this we can find the simple continued fraction expansion of the numbers F(1/2*(sqrt(N^2 + 4) - N)), N a positive integer. The present case is when N = 4. See the Bala link for details.

The theory also provides the simple continued fraction expansion of the numbers F({sqrt(5) - 2}^(2*k+1)), k = 1, 2, 3, ...: if [1; c(1), c(2), 1, c(3), c(4), 1, ...] denotes the present sequence then the simple continued fraction expansion of F({sqrt(5) - 2}^(2*k+1)) is given by [1; c(2*k+1), c(2*(2*k+1)), 1, c(3*(2*k+1)), c(4*(2*k+1)), 1, ...].
